question: At what age should Bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG) be given?
What is the pressure difference between visceral pleura and chest wall pleura called?
Which of the following best explains the vertical model in the doctor-patient relationship?

answers.option: Doctor helps patient find their preferences
Patient plays a mutual role in deciding the treatment plan
Doctor taking entire control which is not apparent virtually
Patient makes all the decisions on their own
Doctor only provides facts to the patient

question: Which of the following structures passes through the diaphragm with the esophagus?
Which of the following is the most helpful and preferred method of establishing the diagnosis of asthma?

A 60-year-old male suffered a stroke that resulted in damage to an area that controls forced expiration during rest and exercise. Which one of the following was most likely affected in this individual?

During strenuous exercise, an athlete's alveolar ventilation increases to 6 L per minute while pulmonary blood flow rises to 7.5 L per minute. Which one of the following V/Q ratios is present at this moment?
Which one of the following factors keeps the pulmonary alveoli dry under normal conditions?

answers.option: Low vapor pressure of water in inspired air

question: A patient has an episode of hematemesis (bloody vomiting). His Hb level is 11 gm/dl before the event of hematemesis. He is treated in a hospital. After 1 day, CBC report shows a Hb level of 10gm/dl. At this level of Hb, what is the oxygen-carrying capacity of his blood?
Which of the following conditions leads to stagnant hypoxia?

A 45-year-old man has been experiencing chronic hypertension with muscle weakness and frequent muscle cramps despite lifestyle modifications and antihypertensive medications. On investigations, he is diagnosed with Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism). Which of the following biochemical characteristics is possible in this patient?

answers.option: Decrease in the ratio of HCO3: H2CO3

question: A 47-year-old female presented to the emergency with a severe asthma attack, sweating, shortness of breath, fatigue, headache, drowsiness, and confusion. On examination, she is found hyperventilating, Her arterial blood gases report showed pH = 7.20, PaCO₂ = 58 mmHg, and HCO₃⁻ = 21 mEq/L. What is the provisional diagnosis of this patient based on ABGs?
A healthy 25-year-old woman reports coughing paroxysms when the temperature goes below freezing. Which of the following sensory receptors may have triggered this response?

A 1-day-old preterm neonate presented with complaints of tachypnea (Increased respiratory rate), respiratory distress, and cyanosis. A history of gestational diabetes mellitus was present in the mother. Which of the following is most likely finding if the amniotic fluid was assessed after 34 weeks of gestation?
"The enzyme responsible for the breakdown of phospholipids into fatty acids and glycerol". The given explanation best corresponds to which of the following enzymes?

Slow-reacting substances of anaphylaxis (SRS-A) are an important regulator in many diseases involving inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions such as asthma. Which of the following explanations best corresponds to slow-reacting substances of anaphylaxis?

answers.option: Mixture of leukotrienes C4, E4, and D4

question: Bicarbonate buffer is an effective physiological extracellular buffer comprising carbonic acid (the proton donor) and bicarbonate (the proton acceptor). Which of the following statements about bicarbonate and its effectiveness as a buffer is accurate?

answers.option: The bicarbonate buffer is most effective at a pH of 7.0, maintaining a neutral environment in the body
Carbonic anhydrase is the primary enzyme that catalyzes the formation of CO2 in the bicarbonate buffer system
Decreased activity of carbonic anhydrase leads to increased plasma bicarbonate concentration
A fall in physiological pH is associated with a state of primary bicarbonate deficit due to decreased plasma bicarbonate concentration
The bicarbonate buffer is most effective at a pH of 6.1, corresponding to the pKa of carbonic acid

question: The presence of which of the following is the main difference between glycerophosphatides and phosphosphingoside?
Which of the following congenital diseases affecting the lungs is most common?

answers.option: Lack of pulmonary surfactant protein B

question: A 32-year-old man is found unresponsive on the street and brought to the emergency department. Emergency personnel found what is presumed to be heroin and a syringe near his body. He is lethargic and cyanotic with symmetric pinpoint pupils. Vital signs are temperature 36.0°C (96.8°F); heart rate 70/min; respiratory rate 6/min; and blood pressure 100/60 mmHg. An arterial blood gas sample (ABG) is drawn in addition to the following laboratory tests: Serum Na+ = 138 mEq/L Serum Cl- = 101 mEq/L. Serum K+ = 4.0 mEq/L Serum creatinine (SCr) = 0.58 mg/dl. What would most likely be seen on this patient's ABG?

answers.option: Decreased pH; decreased PCO2; decreased HCO3-
Decreased pH; increased PCO2; increased HCO3-
Increased pH; decreased PCO2; decreased HCO3-
Normal pH; increased PCO2; increased HCO3-
Increased pH; increased PCO2; increased HCO3-

question: A 35-year-old man has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and has elevated levels of carbon dioxide in his blood, resulting in respiratory acidosis. How would his body attempt to compensate for this respiratory acidosis?

answers.option: The respiratory rate increases to expel more carbon dioxide
The kidneys will absorb H+ ions
The bicarbonate buffer system releases more bicarbonate ions
The kidneys excrete excess bicarbonate ions

question: Which of the following is the least characteristic of asthma?

answers.option: Infiltration of eosinophils in the airway

question: A 50-year-old man (a known patient with rhinitis and polyps) presents to your clinic with a history of repeated asthma attacks and urticaria. On further inquiry, she reports taking aspirin for her lower back pain. What is the most likely cause of her asthma attacks?

answers.option: Aspirin causes increased leukotrienes production which causes bronchospasm
Nasal polyps and rhinitis predispose her to necrotizing bronchial infections
Aspirin damages her distal airways causing them to dilate
She most likely has a positive family history for asthma
Polyps in her nose also cause her to have polyps in her lungs

question: Which of the following statement is correct about the lung diseases?

answers.option: Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expiratory flow rate
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expansion of the lung
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by limitation to air flow
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by limitation to air flow
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expansion of the lung

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate regarding community-acquired pneumonia?

answers.option: The most frequently identified organisms are gram-negative

question: A 75-year-old man has been hospitalized for the past 1 week with COVID-19 pneumonia. He develops sudden onset dyspnea and tachypnea. His lips appear blue and his oxygen saturation drops drastically. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates (white lung). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old healthcare worker, recently exposed to a patient with confirmed pulmonary tuberculosis, is concerned about possible infection. She undergoes a Mantoux tuberculin skin test. Two days later, the test site revealed a 12 mm induration. What mechanism best explains the positive result of the Mantoux test?

answers.option: Activation of neutrophils and tissue destruction
Immediate hypersensitivity to purified protein derivative (PPD)
Activation of B cells and antibody production against TB
Direct activation of mycobacterial antigens in the skin

question: Asthma is a common obstructive lung disease. It is characterized by which of the following pathological changes?

answers.option: Airspace enlargement and wall destruction with no obvious fibrosis
Smooth muscle hyperplasia, excess mucus and inflammation
Necrotizing inflammation and fibrosis of airway walls

question: A 22-year-old female presents with a persistent cough, low-grade fever, and unintentional weight loss of 5 for the past three months. She reports occasional night sweats and a family history of TB. On physical examination, lymph nodes are palpable and there are decreased breath sounds over the right upper lung field. A chest X-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. A fine needle aspiration is performed on the lymph nodes and pus is aspirated. What is the underlying process behind this pus formation?

A 6-week-old infant presents with severe paroxysms of coughing and whooping sounds, along with posttussive emesis. The patient has not received any vaccinations yet. Bordetella pertussis infection is suspected and the patient is treated with antibiotics. Pertussis toxin, a known virulence factor of Bordetella Pertussis plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of the disease. What is the mechanism of action of this toxin?

answers.option: Inhibition of bacterial adhesion to respiratory epithelium
ADP-ribosylation of G proteins, leading to increased cAMP production
Inhibition of neutrophil chemotaxis to the site of infection
Blockade of histamine release from mast cells

question: A 35-year-old male presents with a persistent cough, low-grade fever, and night sweats for the past two months. He reports a history of working in a homeless shelter. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild cervical lymphadenopathy. A chest X-ray shows infiltrates in the right upper lobe. Acid-fast staining of sputum confirms the presence of acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the early events in the infection?

answers.option: Production of exotoxins causing tissue damage
Development of encapsulated cysts in lung parenchyma
Formation of abscesses in lung tissue

question: A 37-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with high fever, cough, and confusion. He is admitted to the hospital and a chest X-ray reveals multifocal, patchy consolidation. A diagnosis of atypical pneumonia is made. On probing, he provides a history of attending a meeting during the last week. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his illness?

A previously healthy 12-month-old child presents with fever, cough, and increased respiratory effort. A chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe consolidation with pleural effusion. Sputum culture grows gram-negative coccobacillary rods on chocolate agar. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male, obese, smoker underwent surgery for a femur fracture. He stayed in the hospital for one week and was on anticoagulant therapy. At home, he suddenly developed dyspnea and cyanosis. He was taken to the hospital but could not survive. Which risk factor is least likely to be associated with his cause of death?

A 35-year-old male with a severe, persistent cough, and expectoration of foul-smelling sputum, particularly frequent when the patient rises in the morning. He also has a history of chronic sinusitis. On chest X-ray, bronchi are dilated, bronchovascular markings are increased, pulmonary vasculature appears ill-defined, representing fibrosis. What are the conditions that predispose to this disease?
Which one of the following is a feature of Kartagener syndrome?
Due to its anti-inflammatory mechanism of action, which of the following medications require regular administration for the treatment of asthma?

Oral medications are popular for the treatment of asthma in children because young children may have difficulty with the proper use of aerosol inhalers. Which of the following is an orally active inhibitor of 5-lipoxygenase enzyme to inhibit leukotrienes?
A patient is advised to take antitubercular therapy for six months. After 12 weeks of treatment, the patient complains of visual defects. Which drug is responsible for this side effect?

A 49-year-old cobbler contracts severe diarrhea due to cholera. He used to drink and eat from the roadside hotels. He has a low BMI with a history of hypertension, and his personal hygiene is poor. He lives in a small space with many other workers. In the above scenario, what is the primary determinant of his acute illness?
A young mother was informed by the birth attendant that her recently born firstborn baby has trisomy 21. The reason for the above-mentioned disease lies at what stage?

A type of learning in which a neutral stimulus is presented repeatedly with one that reflexively elicits a particular response so that the neutral stimulus eventually elicits the response itself is known as classical conditioning. After a certain time, the response becomes extinct but it can re-emerge after a period of time has passed with no further conditioning. What is the name for this phenomenon?
Sarah is in a bad mood and forcefully smiles for 10 seconds. This behavior can be explained by the facial feedback hypothesis. Which of the following does this hypothesis suggest?

answers.option: Once we know how we are feeling, we can change our facial expression
The movement of our facial muscles can trigger emotions
Some people disguise their emotions if they look in a mirror
We can judge someone else's mood by looking at their face

question: The pulmonary function test of a 40-year-old male showed the following values: FEV1/FVC- 65% of predicted TLC- Normal FVC- Normal DLCO- Low What would be the most likely diagnosis from this PFT?

A 13-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of off-and-on shortness of breath for the last few years, especially during winters along with whistling sounds. Which of the following findings on the chest examination would be the most appropriate?
Which one of the following is an example of a post-contrast CT chest?
Which of the following is considered a first-line treatment for the treatment of acute asthma exacerbations?
In addition to oxygen saturation, which of the following parameters should be closely monitored in a patient with acute asthma exacerbation to assess disease severity?

answers.option: Forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1)

question: What is a common trigger for acute asthma exacerbation?

While discussing important clinical landmarks, students consider the significant ones in relation to the division of mediastinum. Which of the following is primarily considered a landmark to divide the mediastinum?
A 60-year-old patient has a profuse amount of fluid in the left pleural cavity due to acute pleurisy. Where would the fluid accumulate?
A patient underwent a chest CT scan that revealed a mass in the anterior mediastinum. Among the following conditions, what is the most likely cause of the mass?

A 4-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department. The mother tells that the boy has swallowed a small bead while playing. Which of the following is the most appropriate reason for this bead to enter the right lung?

answers.option: Right bronchus is narrower than the left one
Right lung is shorter than the left lung
Right lung has one lobe more than left lung
Right bronchus is more vertically placed than the left one
Right lung is heavier than the left lung

question: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding posterior intercostal arteries?

answers.option: All are branches of descending thoracic aorta
Give mammary branches to the breast
Eleven in number on each side

question: Which of the following joints of the thorax is a primary cartilaginous joint?
Which of the following pairs of ribs is classified as vertebrochondral ribs?
Which of the following branches of typical intercostal nerves arise near the angle of ribs?

A patient comes to the chest clinic with the complaint of chest pain felt in the ribs. After examination, a diagnosis of pressure on intercostal nerves was made. This compression on intercostal nerves was leading to spasms of the muscles being innervated by these nerves. Which of the following muscles would be unaffected in this scenario?
In which of the following weeks do the terminal bronchioles become larger to form two or more respiratory bronchioles and primordial alveolar ducts are formed?
Which of the following structures does not participate in forming the thoracoabdominal diaphragm?

The trachea is the part of the conducting portion of the respiratory system. The mucosa is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. Glands in the submucosa cartilage and adventitia. Which of the following structures has the same histological appearance as the trachea?
During chest auscultation, a physician instructs his patient to inhale deeply. Which of the following muscles are accountable for facilitating this ventilation procedure?
A 50-year-old smoker is diagnosed with restrictive lung disease, which affects his lung tissue's ability to expand. Which of the following is most likely to be reduced in this condition?
Which of the following effects on the respiratory system occurs due to parasympathetic stimulation?

answers.option: Bronchodilation due to acetylcholine receptor activation

question: A person is hiking at a high altitude mountain, where the air has a lower oxygen concentration. As a result, they experience changes in their respiratory rate and depth to adapt to the lower oxygen levels. Which of the following physiological mechanisms primarily regulates respiration in this situation?

answers.option: The stretch receptors in the lungs
Central chemoreceptors in the medulla oblongata
Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid bodies

question: In a healthy individual which one of the following is the primary regulating variable of central chemoreceptors?
An 80-year-old obese person has been diagnosed with sleep apnea, a condition where he experiences repeated pauses in breathing during sleep. This is primarily due to which of the following?

answers.option: An increase in blood oxygen levels
A decrease in carbon dioxide levels

question: Repaying the oxygen debt after exercise is primarily achieved to regulate which of the following processes?

answers.option: Reconvert phosphocreatine to creatinine and phosphate
Reconvert the lactic acid back into glucose
Reconvert ATP and ADP to AMP

question: A 20-year-old patient with asthma is prescribed an inhaler that contains a bronchodilator. Which receptors are inhibited by the bronchodilator to help alleviate her asthma symptoms?

A 20-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a fractured rib. The patient experiences painful breathing and thus takes rapid, shallow breaths. His respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute with a tidal volume of 200 ml. What would be his alveolar ventilation rate?

Following a road traffic accident, a 25-year-old young man experiences breathing difficulties. Upon arrival at the emergency department, a lung function test was conducted, revealing a reduction in his functional residual capacity. What does this reduced capacity signify?

answers.option: The volume of air expelled after a standard exhalation
The sum of inspiratory reserve volume and tidal volume
The volume of air inhaled and exhaled during a typical breath
The volume of air that lingers in the lung after a normal exhalation
The volume of air that stays in the lung after a complete exhalation

question: A patient with a history of chronic lung disease is experiencing decreased lung compliance. What is the primary factor contributing to this reduction in lung compliance?

answers.option: Increased elastic recoil of the lungs

question: A 45-year-old male received a penetrating stab wound on the chest wall resulting in intrapleural pressure becoming equal to atmospheric pressure. This change in the pressure would cause which one of the following effects on the lung?

A 70-year-old male who has smoked 50 cigarettes per day for 45 years complains of shortness of breath and is diagnosed with chronic emphysema. Which of the following changes are present in this patient with respect to lung compliance, lung elastic recoil, and total lung capacity as compared to a healthy non-smoker?

answers.option: Pulmonary embolism leading to V/Q mismatch
Right to left shunt in congenital heart disease
Impaired gas exchange secondary to pneumonia

Barometric pressure at sea level?

The amount of air that is expelled out after maximal forceful expiration
